songs.title: Bohemian Rhapsody
songs.fun_fact: Bohemian Rhapsody was initially rejected by record labels who thought a 6-minute operatic rock song would never get radio play. Freddie Mercury spent three weeks recording the complex vocal harmonies, stacking 180 separate overdubs. It became Queen's signature song.

songs.title: Africa
songs.fun_fact: Africa was written by TOTO's David Paich about a man who has never been to Africa but romanticizes the continent. The distinctive keyboard intro was inspired by a documentary about African wildlife. The song has experienced multiple viral revivals decades after release.

songs.title: Angels
songs.fun_fact: Angels was written by Robbie Williams and Guy Chambers in just 25 minutes at Chambers' home. It became the song most requested at British funerals for years. Williams has said it's about his belief in guardian angels and the connection between people.

songs.title: Back In Black
songs.fun_fact: Back In Black was recorded as a tribute to late AC/DC frontman Bon Scott, who died in February 1980. The album of the same name became one of the best-selling records in history. Brian Johnson was selected as Scott's replacement just weeks before recording began.

songs.title: Thriller
songs.fun_fact: Thriller's iconic music video was directed by John Landis and cost $500,000 to produce—unprecedented for the time. It premiered as a 14-minute short film and transformed the music video industry forever. Vincent Price recorded his famous rap in just two takes.

songs.title: Hallelujah
songs.fun_fact: Leonard Cohen wrote approximately 80 draft verses of Hallelujah over five years before settling on the final version. The song was initially ignored but gained fame through Jeff Buckley's 1994 cover. Cohen reportedly worked on verses while sitting in his underwear at hotels.

songs.title: Father and Son
songs.fun_fact: Father and Son features Cat Stevens singing both parts—the father in a deeper voice and the son in a higher register. It was originally written for a musical called Revolussia that was never produced. The song has become an anthem for generational understanding worldwide.

songs.title: Hey Jude
songs.fun_fact: Hey Jude was written by Paul McCartney to comfort John Lennon's son Julian during his parents' divorce. At 7 minutes and 11 seconds, it was the longest single ever to top the UK charts at that time. The famous 'na-na-na' outro was improvised during recording.

songs.title: Summer of '69
songs.fun_fact: Summer of '69 is not about the year 1969—Bryan Adams was only 9 years old then. Adams has confirmed the title refers to the sexual position. The song captures the nostalgic feeling of youthful summers and first bands, becoming a rock radio staple worldwide.

songs.title: Let It Be
songs.fun_fact: Let It Be was inspired by a dream Paul McCartney had about his mother Mary, who died when he was 14. In the dream, she came to him during a troubled time and said 'Let it be.' The gospel-influenced song became The Beatles' final UK number one single.

songs.title: Highway to Hell
songs.fun_fact: Highway to Hell was the last AC/DC album with original vocalist Bon Scott, who died six months after its release. The title refers to the grueling life of touring, not Satanism. Producer Mutt Lange pushed the band toward a more polished sound that defined their future work.

songs.title: Hotel California
songs.fun_fact: Hotel California took the Eagles four months to record and features one of rock's most famous guitar duets. Don Henley has said the song is about the dark underbelly of the American Dream and excess of California. The iconic guitar solo was recorded in one complete take.

songs.title: Another One Bites the Dust
songs.fun_fact: Another One Bites the Dust was initially opposed by Queen's management who thought it was too disco. Michael Jackson personally encouraged the band to release it as a single. John Deacon's bass line was inspired by Chic's 'Good Times' and became a worldwide phenomenon.

songs.title: Beat It
songs.fun_fact: Beat It features Eddie Van Halen's guitar solo, which he recorded for free as a favor. Van Halen reportedly didn't even want credit initially. Michael Jackson wanted to prove he could make a rock song, and the result became one of his most iconic tracks.

songs.title: Immigrant Song
songs.fun_fact: Immigrant Song was inspired by Led Zeppelin's 1970 concert in Iceland. Robert Plant's distinctive war cry was meant to evoke Viking raiders. The band initially resisted releasing it as a single, preferring to keep their music on albums only, but relented due to demand.

songs.title: Rocket Man
songs.fun_fact: Rocket Man was written after Bernie Taupin was inspired by Ray Bradbury's short story 'The Rocket Man.' It was released three weeks before David Bowie's 'Starman,' leading to comparisons between the space-themed songs. Elton John recorded the piano and vocal in one session.

songs.title: Eye of the Tiger
songs.fun_fact: Eye of the Tiger was written in response to Sylvester Stallone's request for a theme song for Rocky III after Queen's 'Another One Bites the Dust' couldn't be licensed. The band wrote it using footage from the first two Rocky films as inspiration. It topped charts worldwide.

songs.title: Thunderstruck
songs.fun_fact: Thunderstruck's opening guitar riff took Angus Young so long to perfect that he developed arm cramps during recording. The technique involves rapid-fire hammer-ons and pull-offs on one string. The song has become AC/DC's most-played track at sporting events globally.

songs.title: Smoke on the Water
songs.fun_fact: Smoke on the Water tells the true story of a fire at the Montreux Casino during a Frank Zappa concert in 1971. Deep Purple watched the fire from across Lake Geneva where they were staying. The smoke literally went over the water, inspiring rock's most famous guitar riff.

songs.title: Stayin' Alive
songs.fun_fact: Stayin' Alive's tempo of 104 BPM matches the ideal rate for performing CPR chest compressions, making it a recommended song for medical training. The song was written in just a few hours during a break in filming Saturday Night Fever. It defined the disco era.

songs.title: We Are the Champions
songs.fun_fact: We Are the Champions has been scientifically proven to be the catchiest song ever written, according to a study by Goldsmiths University. Freddie Mercury wrote it as an audience participation anthem. It's been adopted as a victory song by sports teams worldwide for decades.

songs.title: Take On Me
songs.fun_fact: Take on Me was released three times before becoming a hit. The innovative music video, combining pencil-sketch animation with live action, cost $100,000 and took 16 weeks to produce. The video's success proved that MTV could make or break a song's popularity.

songs.title: T.N.T.
songs.fun_fact: T.N.T. was written about Angus Young's explosive energy on stage and his tendency to blow up amplifiers. The song became AC/DC's concert opener for years. Originally released only in Australia, it became an international hit when the band gained global recognition.

songs.title: Yesterday
songs.fun_fact: Yesterday is the most covered song in history with over 2,200 recorded versions. Paul McCartney woke up with the melody in his head and initially thought he must have subconsciously plagiarized it. The working title was 'Scrambled Eggs' before the lyrics were finalized.

songs.title: Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This)
songs.fun_fact: Sweet Dreams was written by Annie Lennox and Dave Stewart during the breakup of their romantic relationship. The song's synthesizer hook was created accidentally when Stewart misconnected equipment. It became the defining sound of 1980s synth-pop and launched Eurythmics to fame.

songs.title: It's My Life
songs.fun_fact: It's My Life marked Bon Jovi's successful comeback after a five-year hiatus. The song was written to appeal to both longtime fans and a new generation. It has been certified platinum multiple times and became a defining rock anthem of the early 2000s across the globe.

songs.title: Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go
songs.fun_fact: Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go was inspired by a note left by Andrew Ridgeley for his parents. The double 'go-go' came from a scribbling error. George Michael wrote the song in just a few hours, and it became Wham!'s biggest international hit, reaching number one globally.

songs.title: We Will Rock You
songs.fun_fact: We Will Rock You's iconic stomp-stomp-clap beat was designed by Brian May to be performed by stadium audiences. May wanted to create something that 'even a stadium full of people could do.' The song is played at virtually every sporting event worldwide to this day.

songs.title: Wind of Change
songs.fun_fact: Wind of Change was written about the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the Cold War. The Scorpions' Klaus Meine wrote it after visiting Moscow during glasnost. It became an anthem for German reunification and has sold over 14 million copies, symbolizing hope and freedom.

songs.title: Wonderwall
songs.fun_fact: Wonderwall was inspired by Noel Gallagher's then-girlfriend Meg Mathews, though he later said it was about an 'imaginary friend' who'll save you. The title comes from a George Harrison album. It's one of the most-played songs on streaming platforms and a karaoke staple worldwide.

songs.title: Can't Help Falling in Love
songs.fun_fact: Can't Help Falling in Love was adapted from the 18th-century French song 'Plaisir d'Amour.' Elvis Presley performed it at the end of his concerts for years. It was featured in the film Blue Hawaii and has been covered by over 500 artists, becoming a wedding favorite.

songs.title: Forever Young
songs.fun_fact: Forever Young became a Cold War anthem about nuclear annihilation and the desire to live fully despite uncertainty. Alphaville's Marian Gold wrote two versions—one slow and one uptempo—and couldn't decide which to release, so both appeared on the album. It's now a graduation staple.

songs.title: Sweet Caroline
songs.fun_fact: Sweet Caroline was written about Caroline Kennedy, President JFK's daughter, after Neil Diamond saw a photo of her on a magazine cover. Diamond didn't confirm this until 2007. The 'Bah bah bah' hook has made it a stadium singalong favorite, especially at Boston Red Sox games.

songs.title: Stand By Me
songs.fun_fact: Stand By Me was written in the basement of Ben E. King's New York apartment in just 15 minutes. The song was inspired by a gospel hymn. It has been used in over 150 films and TV shows, and was named one of the Songs of the Century by the Recording Industry Association.

songs.title: What a Wonderful World
songs.fun_fact: What a Wonderful World was written specifically for Louis Armstrong's gravelly voice and optimistic persona. It was a commercial failure in the US initially but hit number one in the UK. The song gained renewed popularity after being featured in the 1987 film Good Morning, Vietnam.

songs.title: I Want You Back
songs.fun_fact: I Want You Back was the debut single from the Jackson 5, featuring 11-year-old Michael Jackson on lead vocals. Motown founder Berry Gordy personally oversaw the production. The song showcased Michael's incredible vocal abilities and launched one of music's most legendary careers.

songs.title: Take Me Home, Country Roads
songs.fun_fact: Take Me Home, Country Roads was written about West Virginia by two songwriters who had never visited the state. John Denver added final touches and made it his signature song. It became the official state anthem of West Virginia in 2014, beloved by fans worldwide.

songs.title: We Are the World
songs.fun_fact: We Are the World was recorded in one overnight session with 46 of the biggest stars in music. Producer Quincy Jones posted a sign saying 'Check your egos at the door.' It raised over $63 million for African famine relief and became the fastest-selling American pop single ever.

songs.title: Mamma Mia
songs.fun_fact: Mamma Mia launched a global phenomenon including a stage musical and two films. ABBA's Benny Andersson wrote the distinctive keyboard hook. The song's title and lyrics play with the Italian exclamation. It was ABBA's first UK number one and helped establish them internationally.

songs.title: Sunny
songs.fun_fact: Sunny was originally written by Bobby Hebb in 1963 after the assassination of JFK and his brother's murder. Boney M.'s disco version became one of the biggest hits of 1976. The song has been covered over 300 times, making it one of the most-recorded songs in history.

songs.title: Lemon Tree
songs.fun_fact: Lemon Tree was written by Fools Garden's Peter Freudenthaler about a boring Sunday afternoon spent staring at a lemon tree picture. The German band became one-hit wonders internationally but remain popular in Europe. The song's upbeat melody contrasts with its melancholic lyrics.

songs.title: Don't Worry, Be Happy
songs.fun_fact: Don't Worry, Be Happy was the first a cappella song to reach number one on the Billboard Hot 100. Bobby McFerrin recorded all the vocals himself using only his voice and body percussion. The phrase later became associated with Bob Marley, though he never actually sang those words.

songs.title: Waterloo
songs.fun_fact: Waterloo was ABBA's breakthrough hit that won the 1974 Eurovision Song Contest. The song compares surrender in love to Napoleon's defeat at Waterloo. It was released in both English and Swedish versions and launched ABBA's career as one of the best-selling groups in history.

songs.title: Y.M.C.A.
songs.fun_fact: YMCA was written by Jacques Morali after he visited a YMCA in New York and found it a great place for young people to hang out. The Village People song became a gay anthem and disco classic. The famous arm movements were invented by audience members, not choreographed.

songs.title: September
songs.fun_fact: September's opening line 'Do you remember the 21st night of September?' refers to no specific event—songwriter Allee Willis chose it purely for the sound. Maurice White confirmed there's no special meaning. The song has become an essential party anthem for over four decades now.

songs.title: Mambo No. 5
songs.fun_fact: Mambo No. 5 originally was a 1949 Cuban instrumental. Lou Bega added lyrics listing women's names, which were supposedly real girlfriends. The song became a global phenomenon, topping charts in over 10 countries. Bega reportedly made $6 million from this single alone worldwide.

songs.title: Sweet Home Alabama
songs.fun_fact: Sweet Home Alabama was written as a response to Neil Young's critical songs about the American South. Despite the perceived feud, Young and Lynyrd Skynyrd were actually friends. The song became an anthem for Southern pride and is still played at Alabama Crimson Tide football games.

songs.title: Daddy Cool
songs.fun_fact: Daddy Cool was one of Boney M.'s first major hits, featuring Frank Farian's production techniques that later caused controversy. The song's infectious rhythm made it a disco staple. Farian would later admit to using session singers on some recordings, but Daddy Cool showcased the group's talent.

songs.title: The Final Countdown
songs.fun_fact: The Final Countdown was written about space travel and leaving Earth behind. The iconic synthesizer intro has made it one of the most recognized riffs in rock history. Europe's Joey Tempest was inspired by David Bowie's 'Space Oddity.' The song is played at countless sporting events today.

songs.title: I Love Rock 'n' Roll
songs.fun_fact: I Love Rock 'n' Roll was originally recorded by Arrows in 1975. Joan Jett saw them perform it on British TV and became obsessed with the song. Her version became one of the biggest hits of the early 1980s and defined her career as the queen of rock and roll attitude.

songs.title: Jump
songs.fun_fact: Jump was the first Van Halen song to feature David Lee Roth's idea of using synthesizers prominently. Eddie Van Halen actually disliked the keyboard riff initially. The song's optimistic message about taking risks made it an instant anthem and Van Halen's biggest commercial success.

songs.title: It's Raining Men
songs.fun_fact: It's Raining Men was originally offered to Donna Summer, who rejected it for being too risqué. The Weather Girls turned it into a disco anthem that has endured as a camp classic. Songwriters Paul Jabara and Paul Shaffer wrote it as a humorous celebration of female desire.

songs.title: Should I Stay or Should I Go
songs.fun_fact: Should I Stay or Should I Go was written by Mick Jones about his relationship with Ellen Foley. The Spanish backing vocals were recorded by the band without understanding what they were singing. The song gained renewed fame in the Netflix series 'Stranger Things' decades later.

songs.title: Super Trouper
songs.fun_fact: Super Trouper was named after the follow-spot lights used at concerts. ABBA wrote it during the peak of their fame when they felt exhausted by touring. The opening line 'I was sick and tired of everything' reflected their genuine feelings at the time despite worldwide success.

songs.title: Walking on Sunshine
songs.fun_fact: Walking on Sunshine was rejected by multiple labels before finally being released. The song's relentless optimism has made it one of the most-licensed tracks in advertising history. Katrina Leskanich said she was actually going through a rough time when she recorded the joyful song.

songs.title: Somebody to Love
songs.fun_fact: Somebody to Love was Queen's tribute to gospel music, featuring over 100 vocal overdubs. Freddie Mercury was inspired by Aretha Franklin's gospel-influenced performances. The song showcases Queen's incredible harmonies and Mercury's four-octave vocal range at its absolute finest.

songs.title: Respect
songs.fun_fact: Respect was originally written and recorded by Otis Redding about a man demanding respect from his woman. Aretha Franklin flipped the gender perspective and added the iconic 'R-E-S-P-E-C-T' spelling. It became a feminist and civil rights anthem that defined the soul era of music.

songs.title: Rosanna
songs.fun_fact: Rosanna was written by TOTO's David Paich about actress Rosanna Arquette, who he dated briefly. The complex shuffle rhythm, known as the 'Rosanna Shuffle,' has become a benchmark for drummers worldwide. The song won the Grammy for Record of the Year in 1983 for its innovative sound.

songs.title: Dancing Queen
songs.fun_fact: Dancing Queen remains ABBA's most successful single and the only one to reach number one in the US. It was inspired by George McCrae's 'Rock Your Baby.' ABBA performed it for the first time the night before Sweden's King Carl XVI Gustaf's wedding as a tribute to the new queen.

songs.title: Don't Stop Me Now
songs.fun_fact: Don't Stop Me Now was written by Freddie Mercury during a particularly hedonistic period of his life. Other band members initially disliked it for promoting excess. In 2020, a scientific study named it the 'happiest song ever' based on tempo, lyrics, and key. Mercury's favorite Queen song.

songs.title: I Will Always Love You
songs.fun_fact: I Will Always Love You was written by Dolly Parton in 1973 about her professional split from Porter Wagoner. Whitney Houston's powerful version for The Bodyguard became one of the best-selling singles of all time. Houston held the final note for an incredible 17 seconds in the recording.

songs.title: Surfin' U.S.A.
songs.fun_fact: Surfin' U.S.A. melody was adapted from Chuck Berry's 'Sweet Little Sixteen,' leading to a lawsuit. The Beach Boys' Brian Wilson was forced to give Berry songwriting credit. Despite the controversy, the song captured California surf culture and remains an American classic to this day.

songs.title: Smooth Criminal
songs.fun_fact: Smooth Criminal's distinctive lean was achieved by Michael Jackson using special patented shoes that locked into pegs on the stage floor. Jackson invented and patented this footwear technology. The song's music video was an 11-minute film featuring elaborate choreography and groundbreaking effects.

songs.title: I'm So Excited
songs.fun_fact: I'm So Excited was originally released in 1982 but became a bigger hit when remixed and re-released in 1984. The Pointer Sisters wrote it about the excitement of romantic anticipation. It became a cultural touchstone through its appearance in the famous 'Saved by the Bell' caffeine pill episode.

songs.title: I Wanna Dance with Somebody
songs.fun_fact: I Wanna Dance with Somebody was written specifically for Whitney Houston's powerful voice. Songwriters George Merrill and Shannon Rubicam crafted it as an upbeat complement to her ballads. The song won the Grammy for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance and became a dance floor essential.

songs.title: Uptown Girl
songs.fun_fact: Uptown Girl was written by Billy Joel about supermodel Elle Macpherson, though he later married Christie Brinkley who starred in the music video. The song was inspired by Frankie Valli and The Four Seasons' sound. It became one of Joel's biggest international hits, reaching number one in the UK.

songs.title: Music
songs.fun_fact: Music by John Miles builds from a gentle ballad to a symphonic rock epic with full orchestra. Miles wrote it as a tribute to the power of music itself. The song remains a concert favorite and is considered one of the greatest progressive rock compositions of the 1970s.

songs.title: Don't Stop Believin'
songs.fun_fact: Don't Stop Believin' became the top-selling digital track from the 20th century after its use in The Sopranos finale. Journey's Steve Perry wrote it about his own small-town origins. The song experienced a massive revival three decades after release, introducing it to new generations of fans.

songs.title: Zombie
songs.fun_fact: Zombie was written by Dolores O'Riordan after the 1993 IRA bombing in Warrington that killed two children. The Cranberries' most political song became a worldwide hit and anthem against violence. O'Riordan's distinctive yodel-like vocals made it instantly recognizable and emotionally powerful.

songs.title: I Will Survive
songs.fun_fact: I Will Survive was originally released as a B-side before DJs started playing it in clubs. Gloria Gaynor recorded it in one take despite having just recovered from spinal surgery. The song became a disco anthem and later a symbol of empowerment for the LGBTQ+ community worldwide.

songs.title: Baker Street
songs.fun_fact: Baker Street's iconic saxophone riff was played by Raphael Ravenscroft, who was reportedly paid only £27.50 for the session. He later claimed his royalty check bounced. Gerry Rafferty wrote the song about his frustration with the music industry and London's nightlife scene in the late 1970s.

songs.title: Gimme! Gimme! Gimme!
songs.fun_fact: Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! was originally an ABBA song that became the basis for Madonna's 'Hung Up' in 2005—the first time ABBA approved a sample of their work. The song's driving disco beat and desperate lyrics about loneliness created one of their most dramatic recordings ever produced.

songs.title: Billie Jean
songs.fun_fact: Billie Jean's bass line is one of the most recognized in pop music history. Michael Jackson wrote it about a fan who falsely claimed he was the father of her child. The song was the first video by a Black artist played in heavy rotation on MTV, breaking a significant barrier.

songs.title: Maniac
songs.fun_fact: Maniac was written for the film Flashdance about the story of a steel welder who dreams of becoming a ballet dancer. Michael Sembello originally wrote it about a serial killer but changed the lyrics for the film. The song perfectly captures the 80s workout and aerobics craze phenomenon.

songs.title: Hold the Line
songs.fun_fact: Hold the Line was TOTO's debut single and showcased their exceptional musicianship. The band consisted of session musicians who had played on hundreds of hit records. The guitar riff and keyboard solo became instantly recognizable, establishing TOTO as a major force in rock music.

songs.title: Celebration
songs.fun_fact: Celebration was written by Kool & The Gang's bassist and eunice to commemorate special occasions. The song has been played at countless parties, sports events, and celebrations since its release. It was used extensively during the hostages' return home from Iran in 1981, becoming an American anthem.

songs.title: Basket Case
songs.fun_fact: Basket Case was written by Billie Joe Armstrong about his panic attacks and anxiety before he was diagnosed with panic disorder. Green Day recorded the song in their producer's living room. It became the anthem of 90s punk rock and helped define the pop-punk genre for a generation.

songs.title: Everybody (Backstreet's Back)
songs.fun_fact: Everybody (Backstreet's Back) was released only internationally at first because the US label thought it was too cheesy. The horror-themed music video was inspired by Michael Jackson's 'Thriller.' The song became one of the Backstreet Boys' signature hits and a 90s pop culture milestone.

songs.title: Narcotic
songs.fun_fact: Narcotic launched German band Liquido to international fame. The song's catchy guitar riff and straightforward lyrics about addiction made it an alternative rock staple of the late 1990s. It topped charts across Europe and remains a nostalgic favorite for fans of 90s rock music.

songs.title: Bitter Sweet Symphony
songs.fun_fact: Bitter Sweet Symphony samples an orchestral version of The Rolling Stones' 'The Last Time.' Due to legal issues, the Verve lost all royalties to the Stones until 2019 when Jagger and Richards gave the rights back to Richard Ashcroft. The song defines 90s Britpop melancholy perfectly.

songs.title: Jerk It Out
songs.fun_fact: Jerk It Out was used in the iPod commercial that helped launch it to international success. Swedish band Caesars had been together for years before this breakthrough. The high-energy garage rock song perfectly captured the early 2000s indie rock revival and became a party anthem.

songs.title: Let Me Entertain You
songs.fun_fact: Let Me Entertain You was written by Robbie Williams and Guy Chambers as an anthemic statement of Williams' solo career. The song samples 'Rock DJ' elements and established his reputation as a showman. It became a concert opener for years and defined Williams' provocative stage persona.

songs.title: The Show Must Go On
songs.fun_fact: The Show Must Go On was recorded while Freddie Mercury was gravely ill with AIDS. Mercury reportedly drank vodka to numb his pain during recording, then delivered one of rock's most powerful vocal performances. Brian May said he didn't know how Mercury physically managed to sing it.

songs.title: Let's Twist Again
awards: Grammy - Best Rock and Roll Recording (1962)
songs.fun_fact: Let's Twist Again was written as a sequel to 'The Twist' and won a Grammy Award. Chubby Checker became synonymous with the dance craze that swept America in the early 1960s. The twist was the first modern dance where partners didn't touch, revolutionizing how people danced.

songs.title: Under Pressure
songs.fun_fact: Under Pressure was created during an impromptu jam session between Queen and David Bowie. The famous bass line was played by John Deacon. Bowie and Mercury reportedly clashed over creative control, with each recording vocals separately. The song became a landmark collaboration in rock history.

songs.title: Twist and Shout
songs.fun_fact: Twist and Shout was recorded last during The Beatles' marathon first album session. John Lennon's voice was nearly gone, giving the track its raw, raspy quality. The song was actually a cover, originally recorded by the Top Notes. The Beatles' version became definitive and iconic.

songs.title: The Sound of Silence
songs.fun_fact: The Sound of Silence was originally a flop until a producer added electric instruments without Simon & Garfunkel's knowledge. The duo had broken up by then. When the remixed version became a hit, they reunited and launched one of music's most celebrated partnerships. Truly a tale of serendipity.

songs.title: We Didn't Start the Fire
songs.fun_fact: We Didn't Start the Fire lists 118 historical events and figures from 1949-1989. Billy Joel wrote it after a 21-year-old told him it was a boring time to grow up. Joel memorized all the lyrics by creating mental images and has said he hates performing it live because it's exhausting.

songs.title: Crocodile Rock
songs.fun_fact: Crocodile Rock was Elton John's first US number one single. It was written as a nostalgic tribute to 1950s rock and roll and the fictional dances of that era. The 'la la la' chorus was intentionally silly, capturing the innocent fun of early rock and roll dance hall culture.

songs.title: You Give Love a Bad Name
songs.fun_fact: You Give Love a Bad Name was Bon Jovi's breakthrough hit that launched them to superstardom. The song was co-written with Desmond Child, who helped craft its massive arena rock sound. The opening a cappella scream became one of rock's most dramatic opening lines ever recorded.

songs.title: Smells Like Teen Spirit
songs.fun_fact: Smells Like Teen Spirit was named after a deodorant brand that Kurt Cobain's friend Kathleen Hanna wrote on his wall. Cobain didn't know it was a deodorant. The song's explosive dynamics defined grunge and Generation X. MTV played it constantly, making Nirvana reluctant superstars overnight.

songs.title: Girls Just Want to Have Fun
songs.fun_fact: Girls Just Want to Have Fun was originally written by Robert Hazard as a song from a male perspective. Cyndi Lauper changed pronouns and the tone, transforming it into a feminist anthem. The colorful music video featured Lauper's real mother and helped establish MTV's visual culture.

songs.title: What Is Love
songs.fun_fact: What Is Love was Haddaway's debut single and became a Eurodance classic. The song gained cult status through its use in the Saturday Night Live 'Night at the Roxbury' sketches. The head-bobbing dance move became iconic. Haddaway was genuinely asking a philosophical question about love.

songs.title: Paradise City
songs.fun_fact: Paradise City was inspired by Los Angeles and its promise of fame and fortune. The outro was recorded with the band playing live in the studio for 12 minutes straight. The song's epic length and guitar solos made it a perfect concert closer and one of Guns N' Roses' defining tracks.

songs.title: Flashdance... What a Feeling
songs.fun_fact: Flashdance... What a Feeling was written by Giorgio Moroder and Keith Forsey. Irene Cara co-wrote the lyrics about pursuing dreams against all odds. The song won the Academy Award and Golden Globe for Best Original Song. It captured the aspirational spirit of 1980s pop culture perfectly.

songs.title: Can't Stop
songs.fun_fact: Can't Stop features one of the most recognizable guitar riffs of the 2000s, played by John Frusciante. The song's funk-rock energy showcased Red Hot Chili Peppers at their peak. Chad Smith's drumming on this track is considered some of his best work with the band.

songs.title: I Want It That Way
songs.fun_fact: I Want It That Way was written by Max Martin, who went on to become one of pop's most successful producers. Backstreet Boys admit the lyrics don't make complete grammatical sense, but Martin convinced them the emotion mattered more. It remains one of the best-selling singles of all time.

songs.title: Livin' on a Prayer
songs.fun_fact: Livin' on a Prayer tells the story of Tommy and Gina, working-class characters struggling to survive. Jon Bon Jovi initially disliked the song's talk-box effect but was convinced by producer. The song became one of the most-played rock anthems at sporting events and karaoke nights worldwide.

songs.title: Sweet Child O' Mine
awards: American Music Award - Favorite Pop/Rock Single (1989)
songs.fun_fact: Sweet Child O' Mine's iconic guitar riff was actually a warm-up exercise Slash was playing. Axl Rose overheard it and demanded they turn it into a song. The song was written in just five days. It became Guns N' Roses' biggest hit and one of rock's most beloved ballads.

songs.title: In the End
songs.fun_fact: In the End became Linkin Park's signature song and defined the nu-metal era. Mike Shinoda's rapping combined with Chester Bennington's singing created their distinctive sound. The song's themes of trying hard but ultimately failing resonated with millions of fans worldwide, becoming a generational anthem.
